  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
The U.S. Congress and President Bush are facing off
  in a historic showdown. Earlier today the Senate followed the House’s
  lead and passed legislation that would begin the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq this fall – but the
  president has promised to veto it. Sharyl Attkisson will report from Washington, D.C., on
  the battle over Iraq.
 
We’ll also show you some of the results of a
  new CBS News/New York Times poll, which includes Americans’ opinions
  about the troop withdrawal bill as well as the environment. For complete poll
  results this evening, go to CBSNews.com.
 
Tonight is an important milestone in the race for
  2008 – the first debate of the Democratic presidential candidates. Our
  new senior political correspondent Jeff Greenfield will report that this South Carolina event
  will be a major test for the eight contenders, each of whom will only have a
  short time to make a lasting impression.
 
China
  is still denying that the chemical melamine contaminated pet food and led to
  the deaths of dozens of pets. But Chinese officials have offered to cooperate
  with broader inspections of these products. Nancy Cordes will tell you what
  other foodstuffs enter the United States
  from China
  and Barry Peterson will report on how those products are inspected. What they’ve
  found might surprise you.
 
Finally, we’ll have the story of a gospel
  choir found in an unexpected place. Steve Hartman will share their songs in
  this special Thursday edition of Assignment America.
 
I hope you’ll join us tonight for these
  stories and an early look at Scott Pelley’s exclusive 60 Minutes
  interview with former CIA director George Tenet.
 
Thanks,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
